p:
The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) is also an important parameter to consider when evaluating the electrocatalytic activity of a material and can provide a very good indicator of substantial changes at the electrode interface
16, 17 . The proportional relationship between the double layer capacitance (C dl) and ECSA suggests that materials with the same values of C dl should have the same ECSA
18 . A higher ECSA after cycling could indicate that the enhancement of electrocatalytic activity was due to an increase in surface area upon cycling. However, the striking similarity of C dl = 3.17 mF cm −2 and 3.20 mF cm −2 (for the material before and after cycling, respectively) rules out any significant improvement in catalytic performance due to a change in morphology or surface area (Supplementary Fig. 19).
